facts.text: Appeal filed as C.A. No. 2509 of 1969 under Section 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from Madhya Pradesh High Court, Indore Bench judgment dated 30 September 1969 in Election Petitions Nos. 19 and 19A of 1967

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION C.A. No. 2509 of 1969. Appeal under Section 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the Judgement and Order dated the 30th September, 1969 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court, Indore Bench in Election Petitions Nos. 19 and 19A of 1967.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court set aside the election of the appellant by judgment dated 30 September 1969

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from the judgment dated 30 September, 1969 of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh setting, aside the election of the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant, respondent Jagjiwan Joshi and two others were candidates in Jawad Constituency for Madhya Pradesh Assembly general election in 1967; appellant was successful

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and the respondent Jagjiwan Joshi and the other two respondents were four candidates from Jawad Constituency for election to the Madhya Pradesh Assembly at the general election held in the year 1967. The appellant was successful at the election.

facts.text: Respondent Joshi challenged appellant's election

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Joshi challenged the election of the appellant.

facts.text: High Court held appellant guilty of corrupt practice under section 123(4) RPA for speech at Singoli on 29 January 1967 alleging Congress paid Rs. 5000 to Kajod Dhakad to split Jan Sangh votes

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held the appellant to be guilty of companyrupt practice under section 123 4  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951  hereinafter referred to-as the Act  with reference to a speech at Singoli on 29 January, 1967 ... The Congress candidate has on payment of Rs. 5000 set up Kajod Dhakad so that the Jan Sangh votes may be split and he might win.

facts.text: High Court held appellant guilty of corrupt practice under section 123(4) for speech at Athana on 9 February 1967 alleging Joshi paid Rs.5000 to Kajod Dhakad and set up man with knife to attack appellant

anchor.surface_text: a speech at Athana on 9 February, 1967 ... Joshi has set up Kajod Dhakad on payment of Rs. 5000. ... Shri Joshi has set up a man to hit me with a knife.

facts.text: High Court held appellant guilty of corrupt practice under sections 123(3) and 123(2) for speech at Jhatla on 12 February 1967 appealing on religion and threatening divine displeasure for voting Congress on sacred day 20 February 1967

anchor.surface_text: a speech at Jhatia on 12 February, 1967. The High Court further held the appellant to be guilty of companyrupt practice of appealing on the ground of religion as defined in section 123 3  of the Act and also threatening the electors, with divine displeasure ... The votes shall be cast on the 20th and it is fortunate that it is a sacred day being a Monday gyaras. To give a vote to the company- killing Congress on that day is equivalent to cutting down one company and it will be on you to bear the responsibility for this sin.

facts.text: High Court held appellant guilty of corrupt practice for three speeches by Swamiji of Bhanpura on 15 February 1967 at Morwan, Singoli and Diken appealing on religion, threatening divine displeasure for voting Congress, at instance and in presence of appellant after introduction

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also held the appellant to be guilty of companyrupt practice of appealing on the ground of religion and threatening with divine displeasure those who voted for the Congress in the three speeches delivered on 15 February, 1967 at Morwan, Singoli and Diken by the Swamiji of Bhanpura at the instance, and in the presence, and after introduction by the appellant of the Swamiji of Bhanpura to the audience at those three places.

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered order on 31 January 1972 holding disagreement with High Court findings and appellant not guilty of any corrupt practice, reasons to follow

anchor.surface_text: On 31 January, 1972 we delivered the order holding that we did number agree with the finding of the High Court and we also held the appellant to be number guilty of any companyrupt practice. We stated then that we would give the reasons later.

facts.text: High Court accepted oral evidence of respondent and witnesses P.W.1 Kishan Lal Teli, P.W.2 Ghisa Dhakad, P.W.5 Laxmi Lal, P.W.6 Chand Mohammad regarding Athana speech; rejected appellant's witnesses

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted the oral evidence of the respondent and four witnesses Kishan Lal Teli P.W. 1, Ghisa Dhakad P.W. 2, Laxmi Lal P.W. 5 and Chand Mohammad P.W. 6. The High Court did number accept the oral evidence of the appellant or of the witnesses on behalf of the appellant.

facts.text: Election petition affidavit by respondent did not disclose sources of information regarding alleged speeches

anchor.surface_text: The affidavit did number disclose the source of information in respect of the speeches alleged to have been made by the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court found respondent's witnesses for Athana speech tutored, interested, partisan, speaking in identical words, not credible

anchor.surface_text: The entire evidence on behalf of the respondent is tutored and prompted to support the respondent. The High Court was wrong in relying on the oral evidence of the respondent and his witnesses.

facts.text: Respondent had written notes of Athana speech by Ram Kumar Aggarwal but did not produce them or examine him

anchor.surface_text: the respondent said that he had a written report about the alleged speech at Athana and the report was given to the respondent by Ram Kumar Aggarwal. Ram Kumar Aggarwal was also a candidate ... Ram Kumar Aggarwal was number examined as a witness. The written numberes of Ram. Kumar Aggarwal were admitted by the respondent to be with him.

facts.text: Supreme Court found no contemporaneous documentary evidence supporting respondent's allegations

anchor.surface_text: There is number a single piece of documentary evidence to support the case of the respondent.

facts.text: Supreme Court found witnesses for Jhatla speech spoke in identical words, tutored, not credible

anchor.surface_text: Witnesses on behalf of the respondent gave the impression that they never mentioned to anyone about what they knew ... These features indicate that the witnesses appeared to give a semblance of disinterestedness whereas in fact they were all tutored to support the case of the respondent.

facts.text: Supreme Court found witnesses for Singoli 29 Jan 1967 speech interested Congress workers, tutored, not credible

anchor.surface_text: These witnesses establish without any doubt that they were number truthful witnesses but came prepared to support the respondents case.

facts.text: Supreme Court found evidence of Swamiji speeches at Morwan, Singoli, Diken on 15 Feb unreliable, witnesses tutored using prepared notes like Exhibit R-1/27

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit R- 1/27 is a document which companytains the date and hour of the meeting at Morwan, the text of the speech at Morwan. ... The respondent said that he had prepared such numberes for every meeting.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court judgment and dismisses election petition

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons the judgment of the High Court is set aside. The election petition is dismissed.

facts.text: Trial in High Court lasted over 180 days

anchor.surface_text: The trial in the High Court lasted over 180 days.

facts.text: Voting was to be held on 20 February 1967, a Monday gyaras sacred day

anchor.surface_text: The votes shall be cast on the 20th and it is fortunate that it is a sacred day being a Monday gyaras.

issues.text: Whether the appellant committed corrupt practice under section 123(4) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 by alleging payment of Rs.5000 to Kajod Dhakad in speeches at Singoli on 29 January 1967 and Athana on 9 February 1967

anchor.surface_text: The allegations under section 123 4 of the Act fall under two classes. The first relates to the speech delivered by the appellant at Singoli on 29 January, 1967 and a speech delivered by the appellant at Athana on 9 February, 1967. The speech at Singoli was alleged to be as follows -- The Congress candidate has on payment of Rs. 5000 set up Kajod Dhakad so that the Jan Sangh votes may be split and he might win. If he practises such corruption

issues.text: Whether the appellant committed corrupt practice under section 123(4) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 by alleging that the respondent set up a man to hit the appellant with a knife in speeches at Athana on 9 February 1967 and Jhatla on 12 February 1967

anchor.surface_text: The other allegations of corrupt practice under section 123 4 of the Act were in relation to. the same speech at Athana on 9 14-L1061SupCI/72 February, 1967 and a speech at Jhatla on 12 February, 1967. The alleged speech at Athana was as follows Shri Joshi has set up a man to hit me with a knife. Accordingly, if he becomes a legislator the rule of violence  goonda gardi  would be permanently established. Therefore, the public should not only defeat such bad characters

issues.text: Whether the appellant committed corrupt practice under sections 123(3) and 123(2) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 in the speech at Jhatla on 12 February 1967 by appealing on ground of religion and threatening divine displeasure

anchor.surface_text: guilty of corrupt practice of appealing on the ground of religion as defined in section 123(3) of the Act and also threatening the electors, with divine displeasure being a corrupt practice as defined in section 123(2) of the Act in regard to the speech at Jhatla on 12 February, 1967. The allegations of corrupt practice as defined in sections 123 2  and 123 3  of the Act in relation to the same speech at Jhatla on 12 February, 1967 were as follows - The votes shall be cast on the 20th and it is fortunate that it is a sacred day being a Monday gyaras.

issues.text: Whether the speeches by Swamiji of Bhanpura at Morwan, Singoli and Diken on 15 February 1967 at the instance and in presence of the appellant constituted corrupt practices under sections 123(3) and 123(2) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also held the appellant to be guilty of corrupt practice of appealing on the ground of religion and threatening with divine displeasure those who voted for the Congress in the three speeches delivered on 15 February, 1967 at Morwan, Singoli and Diken by the Swamiji of Bhanpura at the instance, and in the presence, and after introduction by the appellant of the Swamiji of Bhanpura to the audience at those three places. The allegations of corrupt practice within the meaning of sections 123 2  and 123 3  of the Act against the appellant in regard to three speeches

issues.text: Whether the failure to disclose sources of information in the affidavit accompanying the election petition under Section 83 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 renders the petition defective or fatal

anchor.surface_text: Section 83 of the Act requires an affidavit in the prescribed form in support of allegations of corrupt practice. The respondent filed an affidavit along with the election petition. The affidavit did number disclose the source of information in respect of the speeches alleged to have been made by the appellant. Rule 94-A of the Conduct of Election Rules 1961 requires an affidavit to be in form No. 25. Form No. 25 requires the deponent to state which statements are true to knowledge and which statements are true to information. Under section 87 of the Act very election petition shall be tried by the High Court as nearly as may be

holdings.text: The Court does not agree with the finding of the High Court and holds the appellant to be not guilty of any corrupt practice.

anchor.surface_text: On 31 January, 1972 we delivered the order holding that we did number agree with the finding of the High Court and we also held the appellant to be number guilty of any companyrupt practice. We stated then that we would give the reasons later.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in accepting respondent's tutored, partisan oral evidence without documentary corroboration for all alleged speeches; witnesses unreliable across all instances.

holdings.text: Non-disclosure of sources of information in the election petition affidavit is not a fatal defect where the trial has proceeded fully.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel on behalf of the appellant companytended that number-dis- closure of the sources of information in the affidavit was a fatal defect and the petition should number have been entertained. It is number necessary to express any opinion on that companytention in view of the fact that the matter was heard for several months in the High Court and thereafter the appeal was heard by this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial completed in High Court and appeal heard; no need to decide fatality, but non-disclosure affects credibility assessment.

holdings.text: The grounds or sources of information are required to be set out in the affidavit accompanying an election petition.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel on behalf of the respondent sub- mitted that the decisions of this Court were number on election petitions. The rulings of this Court are companysistent. The grounds or sources of information are to be set out in the affidavit whether the Code applies or number.

holdings.reasoning_summary: RPA s83, CER Rule 94A Form 25, MP HC Rules 7 & 9, CPC O19 require disclosure to test genuineness; consistent with Supreme Court precedents.

holdings.text: The entire evidence on behalf of the respondent regarding the Athana speech is tutored and prompted; High Court was wrong in relying on it.

anchor.surface_text: The entire evidence on behalf of the respondent is tutored and prompted to support the respondent. The High Court was wrong in relying on the oral evidence of the respondent and his witnesses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Witnesses partisan, identical phrasing/sequence, attended only that meeting, non-production of Ram Kumar Aggarwal's notes, no documentary evidence.

holdings.text: Witnesses for Singoli speech on 29 January 1967 not truthful but came prepared to support respondent's case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partisan Congress workers, added unsupported details (sugar tax), suspicious singular attendance, linked to receipts/minutes disproving independence.

holdings.text: Unable to accept evidence that Swamiji's speeches at Morwan, Singoli, Diken appealed to religion or threatened divine displeasure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Witnesses coached via prepared notes (Ex R-1/27), identical recitals, non-production of other notes, partisan.

holdings.text: High Court wrong in making observations on first information report as criminal case pending.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was wrong in pronouncing observations on the report lodged by Petlia. We are unable to accept the views of the High Court on the report lodged by Petlia inasmuch as the criminal case is pending.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Criminal proceedings pending; observations should not affect magistrate's judgment.

holdings.text: Judgment of the High Court is set aside and the election petition is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons the judgment of the High Court is set aside. The election petition is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No proof of any corrupt practice due to unreliable evidence.

precedents.citation: State of Bombay v. Parshottam Jog Naik, 1952, S.C.R. 674

anchor.surface_text: One of the earliest decisions is State of Bombay v. Parshottam Jog Naik, 1952, S.C.R. 674, where this Court endorsed the decision of the Calcutta High Court in Padmabati Dasi v. Rasik Lal Dhar, I.L.R. 37 Cal. 259, and held that the sources of information should be clearly disclosed.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. Parshottam Jog Naik
precedents.cited_proposition: sources of information should be clearly disclosed in affidavits

precedents.citation: Padmabati Dasi v. Rasik Lal Dhar, I.L.R. 37 Cal. 259

anchor.surface_text: One of the earliest decisions is State of Bombay v. Parshottam Jog Naik, 1952, S.C.R. 674, where this Court endorsed the decision of the Calcutta High Court in Padmabati Dasi v. Rasik Lal Dhar, I.L.R. 37 Cal. 259, and held that the sources of information should be clearly disclosed.

precedents.case_name: Padmabati Dasi v. Rasik Lal Dhar
precedents.cited_proposition: sources of information should be clearly disclosed in affidavits

precedents.citation: Barium Chemicals Ltd. Anr. v. Company Law Board and Ors., 1966 Supp. S.C.R. 331

anchor.surface_text: Again, in Barium Chemicals Ltd. Anr. v. Company Law Board and Ors., 1966 Supp. S.C.R. 331, this Court deprecated slip short verifications, in an affidavit and reiterated the ruling of this Court in Bombay, case  suppra  that verification should invariably be modelled on the lines of Order 19 rule 3 of the Code Whether the Code applies in term, or number.

precedents.case_name: Barium Chemicals Ltd. Anr. v. Company Law Board and Ors.
precedents.cited_proposition: slipshod verifications in affidavits deprecated; verification should be modelled on Order 19 rule 3 CPC

precedents.citation: A. K. K. Nambiar v. Union of India, 1970 3 S.C.R. 121

anchor.surface_text: Again, in A. K. K. Nambiar v. Union of India, 1970 3 S.C.R. 121 this Court said that the importance of verification is to test the genuineness and authenticity of allegations and also to make the deponent responsible for allegations.

precedents.case_name: A. K. K. Nambiar v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: importance of verification in affidavits is to test genuineness and authenticity of allegations and make deponent responsible

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons the judgment of the High Court is set aside. The election petition is dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Judgment of the High Court set aside and election petition dismissed
